title: Loss of Primary Barrier During Operations
operationalFocus: Real-time decision making when barriers are compromised
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are drilling at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD with {{currentSection.mudWeight.current}} ppg mud. Pore pressure is {{scenario.porePressure}} ppg. While pulling out of hole for a bit change, returns stop and you observe {{scenario.lossVolume}} bbls lost into the formation. Your mud weight is now {{scenario.underbalance}} ppg BELOW pore pressure due to the reduced hydrostatic column. What is your immediate response?

underbalance.description: ppg below PP due to losses

correctSequence: 1. Stop pipe movement immediately - do not continue pulling
2. Position tool joint at rotary (prepare for potential shut-in)
3. Fill the hole - pump mud to restore hydrostatic column
4. Monitor for flow - losses can mask a kick
6. If no flow, assess: continue POOH with caution or run back to bottom?
7. Prepare LCM treatment for when back on bottom

answerOptions.A: Continue pulling out - get the bit to surface quickly before the well kicks
answerOptions.B: Stop pipe movement, fill the hole, monitor for flow, prepare for shut-in if needed
answerOptions.C: Immediately shut in the well to prevent further losses
answerOptions.D: Run back to bottom as fast as possible to circulate out any influx

feedback.correct: Correct. When you lose returns, you've lost your primary barrier (hydrostatic). First priority is to restore it by filling the hole. But be vigilant - losses can mask a kick. The well may be taking fluid AND taking a kick simultaneously. Stop moving pipe and assess.
feedback.A_feedback: Dangerous. Continuing to pull reduces hydrostatic further and increases swab effect. You're inviting a kick.
feedback.C_feedback: You can't shut in on losses - there's no pressure to hold. Shutting in with a fractured zone below you traps you. Fill first, then assess for flow.
feedback.D_feedback: Running pipe back quickly creates surge pressure which could worsen losses. Move deliberately, fill the hole, monitor.

contextualTip: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, the tight MW window means losses are a real risk. Lost circulation and kicks can occur simultaneously - this is the most dangerous well control scenario. Always fill the hole and monitor.
advancedNote: Loss of barrier scenarios require supervisor judgment. There's no single correct answer - you must balance kick risk, loss severity, pipe position, and formation characteristics. Pre-plan your response based on the well's PPFG and hazards.
